This is a timeline of '''women in mathematics'''.
==Timeline== 350‚Äì370 until 415: The lifetime of [[Hypatia]], a Greek Alexandrine Neoplatonist philosopher in [[Roman Egypt|Egypt]] who was the first well-documented woman in mathematics.<ref name="socrates">{{Cite book|title=Ecclesiastical History|last=Scholasticus|first=Socrates|authorlink=Socrates Scholasticus|year=|publisher=|location=|isbn=|url=http://cosmopolis.com/alexandria/hypatia-bio-socrates.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090418015156/http://www.cosmopolis.com/alexandria/hypatia-bio-socrates.html|archivedate=2009-04-18|df=}}</ref>
1748: Italian mathematician [[Maria Gaetana Agnesi|Maria Agnesi]] published the first book discussing both differential and integral calculus, called ''Instituzioni analitiche ad uso della giovent√π italiana''.<ref>According to [[Dirk Jan Struik]], Agnesi is "the first important woman mathematician since [[Hypatia of Alexandria|Hypatia]] (fifth century A.D.)".</ref><ref name="epigenesys">{{cite web|url=http://www.epigenesys.eu/index.php/en/science-and-you/women-in-science/665-maria-gaetana-agnesi|title=Epigenesys - Maria Gaetana Agnesi | Women in science|publisher=epigenesys.eu|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
1759: French mathematician [[√âmilie du Ch√¢telet]]'s translation and commentary on Isaac Newton's work ''Principia Mathematica'' was published posthumously; it is still considered the standard French translation.<ref name="brooklynmuseum">{{cite web|url=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/heritage_floor/emilie_du_chatelet.php|title=Brooklyn Museum: Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art: The Dinner Party: Heritage Floor: Emilie du Chatelet|publisher=brooklynmuseum.org|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
1827: French mathematician [[Sophie Germain]] saw her theorem, known as [[Sophie Germain's theorem|Germain's Theorem]], published in a footnote of a book by the mathematician [[Adrien-Marie Legendre]].<ref name="agnesscott.edu">{{cite web|url=http://www.agnesscott.edu/lriddle/women/germain.htm|title=Sophie Germain|publisher=agnesscott.edu|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref><ref name="rochester">{{cite web|url=http://www.math.rochester.edu/people/faculty/doug/UGpages/sophie.html|title=Sophie Germain page|publisher=math.rochester.edu|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref> In this theorem Germain proved that if ''x'', ''y'', and ''z'' are integers and if ''x''<sup>5</sup> + ''y''<sup>5</sup> = ''z''<sup>5</sup> then either ''x'', ''y'', or ''z'' must be divisible by 5. Germain's theorem was a major step toward proving [[Fermat's last theorem]] for the case where n equals 5.<ref name="agnesscott.edu"/>
1829: The first public examination of an American girl in [[geometry]] was held.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O4kEAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA36&lpg=PA36&dq=the+first+public+examination+of+a+girl+in+geometry+(1829)&source=bl&ots=iP5ShzK5u-&sig=sBOKjFQxaCHgVm10oM2EE4g1BNg&hl=en&ei=U-iYTdm4D-GS0QHBpZj6Cw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&sqi=2&ved=0CBQQ6AEwAA# |title=History of Woman Suffrage: 1848‚Äì1861, Volume 1|page= 36|editor1=Elizabeth Cady Stanton |editor2=Susan B. Anthony |editor3=Matilda Joslyn Gage |editor4=Ida Husted Harper |date=1889 |accessdate=2011-04-18}}</ref>
1874: Russian mathematician [[Sofia Kovalevskaya]] became the first woman in modern Europe to gain a doctorate in mathematics, which she earned from the [[University of G√∂ttingen]] in Germany.<ref name="britannica.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/323006/Sofya-Vasilyevna-Kovalevskaya|title=Sofya Vasilyevna Kovalevskaya (Russian mathematician) -- Encyclop√¶dia Britannica|publisher=britannica.com|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
1880: [[Charlotte Angas Scott]] of Britain obtained special permission to take the [[Cambridge Mathematical Tripos]] Exam, as women were not normally allowed to sit for the exam. She came eighth on the Tripos of all students taking them, but due to her sex, the title of "eighth [[Wrangler (University of Cambridge)|wrangler]]," a high honour, went officially to a male student.<ref name=kenschaft>{{cite book|title="Charlotte Angas Scott (1858‚Äì1931)" in Women of Mathematics: A Biobibliographic Sourcebook|year=1987|publisher=Greenwood Press|location=New York|isbn=0-313-24849-4|pages=193‚Äì203|author=Patricia Clark Kenschaft|authorlink=Patricia Clark Kenschaft}}</ref> At the ceremony, however, after the seventh wrangler had been announced, all the students in the audience shouted her name. Because she could not attend the award ceremony, Scott celebrated her accomplishment at Girton College where there were cheers and clapping at dinner, and a special evening ceremony where the students sang "See the Conquering Hero Comes", and she received an ode written by a staff member, and was crowned with laurels.<ref name=kenschaft />
1886: [[Winifred Edgerton Merrill]] became the first American woman to earn a PhD in mathematics, which she earned from Columbia University.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ams.org/notices/201204/rtx120400504p.pdf |title=Winifred Edgerton Merrill : "She Opened the Door" |publisher=Ams.org |accessdate=2014-03-04}}</ref>
1888: The [[Kovalevskaya top]], one of a brief list of known examples of integrable rigid body motion, was discovered by [[Sofia Kovalevskaya]].<ref>S. Kovalevskaya, Sur Le Probleme De La Rotation D'Un Corps Solide Autour D'Un Point Fixe, Acta Mathematica 12 (1889) 177‚Äì232.</ref><ref>[[E. T. Whittaker]], A Treatise on the Analytical Dynamics of Particles and Rigid Bodies, Cambridge University Press (1952).</ref>
1889: [[Sofia Kovalevskaya]] was appointed as the first female professor in Northern Europe, at the [[University of Stockholm]].<ref name="britannica.com"/><ref name="chai-x">{{cite web|url=http://www.chai-x.nl/blog.php?post=10|title=COOL, CREATIEF, HIP met ICT - Innovative women|publisher=chai-x.nl|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
1890: British woman [[Philippa Fawcett]] became the first woman to obtain the top score in the [[Cambridge Mathematical Tripos]] Exam.<ref name="agnesscott">{{cite web|url=http://www.agnesscott.edu/lriddle/women/fawcett.htm|title=Philippa Garrett Fawcett|publisher=agnesscott.edu|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref><ref name="smithsonianmag">{{cite web|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/the-woman-who-bested-the-men-at-math-120480965/|title=The Woman Who Bested the Men at Math | History | Smithsonian|publisher=smithsonianmag.com|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
1913: American mathematician [[Mildred Sanderson]] published her theorem about modular invariants in her thesis. It states: ‚ÄúTo any modular invariant i of a system of forms under any group G of linear transformations with coefficients in the GF[pn], there corresponds a formal invariant I under G such that I = i for all sets of values in the field of the coefficients of the system of forms.‚Äù She was [[Leonard Dickson]]‚Äôs first female graduate student, and he later wrote of her thesis, ‚ÄúThis paper is a highly important contribution to this field of work; its importance lies partly in the fact that it establishes a correspondence between modular and formal invariants. Her main theorem has already been frequently quoted on account of its fundamental character. Her proof is a remarkable piece of mathematics.‚Äù [[E.T. Bell]] wrote, ‚ÄúMiss Sanderson‚Äôs single contribution (1913) to modular invariants has been rated by competent judges as one of the classics of the subject.‚Äù<ref name="agnesscott2">{{cite web|url=http://www.agnesscott.edu/lriddle/women/sander.htm|title=Mildred Leonora Sanderson|publisher=agnesscott.edu|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
1918: German mathematician [[Emmy Noether]] published Noether's (first) theorem, which states that any [[derivative|differentiable]] [[Symmetry in physics|symmetry]] of the [[action (physics)|action]] of a physical system has a corresponding [[Conservation law (physics)|conservation law]].<ref>{{cite journal | author = Noether E | year = 1918 | title = Invariante Variationsprobleme | journal = Nachr. D. K√∂nig. Gesellsch. D. Wiss. Zu G√∂ttingen, Math-phys. Klasse | volume = 1918 | pages = 235‚Äì257 }}</ref>
1927: American mathematician [[Anna Johnson Pell Wheeler|Anna Pell-Wheeler]] became the first woman to present a lecture at the [[American Mathematical Society]] Colloquium.<ref name="agnesscott3">{{cite web|url=http://www.agnesscott.edu/lriddle/women/prizes.htm|title=Prizes, Awards, and Honors for Women Mathematicians|publisher=agnesscott.edu|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
1930: [[Cecilia Krieger|Cecilia Kreiger]] became the first woman to earn a PhD in mathematics in Canada, at the [[University of Toronto]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/cecilia-krieger/|title=Cecilia Krieger|last=Zuschlag|first=Anna|work=The Canadian Encyclopedia|access-date=2018-08-22|language=en}}</ref>
1930s: British mathematician [[Mary Cartwright]] proved her theorem, now known as [[Cartwright's theorem]], which gives an estimate for the maximum modulus of an analytic function that takes the same value no more than p times in the unit disc. To prove the theorem she used a new approach, applying a technique introduced by [[Lars Ahlfors]] for conformal mappings.<ref name="st-and">{{cite web|url=http://www-history.mcs.st-and.ac.uk/Biographies/Cartwright.html|title=Cartwright biography|publisher=-history.mcs.st-and.ac.uk|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
1943: [[Euphemia Haynes]] became the first African-American woman to earn a Ph.D. in mathematics, which she earned from Catholic University.<ref name="buffalo">{{cite web|url=http://www.math.buffalo.edu/mad/PEEPS/haynes.euphemia.lofton.html|title=Euphemia Lofton Haynes, first african american woman mathematician|publisher=math.buffalo.edu|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
1949: American mathematician [[Gertrude Mary Cox]] became the first woman elected into the [[International Statistical Institute]].<ref name="agnesscott4">{{cite web|url=http://www.agnesscott.edu/lriddle/women/cox.htm|title=Gertrude Mary Cox|publisher=agnesscott.edu|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
1956: American mathematician [[Gladys West]] began collecting data from satellites at the [[Naval Surface Warfare Center Dahlgren Division]]. Her calculations directly impacted the development of accurate [[GPS system]]s.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://gpsworld.com/how-gladys-west-uncovered-the-hidden-figures-of-gps/|title=How Gladys West uncovered the ‚ÄòHidden Figures‚Äô of GPS|date=2018-03-19|work=GPS World|access-date=2018-09-22|language=en-US}}</ref>
1962: American mathematician [[Mina Rees]] became the first woman to win the Yueh-Gin Gung and Dr. Charles Y. Hu Award for Distinguished Service to Mathematics, which is the most prestigious award made by the Mathematical Association of America.<ref name="agnesscott3"/>
1964: [[Mary Cartwright]] became the first woman to win the [[Sylvester Medal]] of the Royal Society of London, which is given every three years since 1901 for the encouragement of mathematical research, without regard to nationality.<ref name="agnesscott3"/>
1966: American mathematician and [[physics]] professor [[Mary L. Boas]] published ''[[Mathematical Methods in the Physical Sciences]]'', which was still widely used in college classrooms as of 1999.<ref>[http://condor.depaul.edu/~physics/people/index.html DePaul Department of Physics] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100619130842/http://condor.depaul.edu/~physics/people/index.html |date=2010-06-19 }}</ref><ref name="Boas1966">{{cite book|author=Mary L. Boas|title=Mathematical methods in the physical sciences|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RuPuAAAAMAAJ|year=1966|publisher=Wiley}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Spector|first=Donald|title=Book Reviews|journal=[[American Journal of Physics]]|year=1999|volume=67|issue=2|pages=165‚Äì169|doi=10.1119/1.19216}}</ref>
1968: [[Mary Cartwright]] became the first woman to win the [[De Morgan Medal]], the London Mathematical Society's premier award.<ref name="agnesscott3"/>
1970: American mathematician [[Mina Rees]] became the first female president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.<ref name="agnesscott5">{{cite web|url=http://www.agnesscott.edu/lriddle/women/rees.htm|title=Mina Rees|publisher=agnesscott.edu|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
1971: American mathematician [[Mary Ellen Rudin]] constructed the first [[Dowker space]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.massey.ac.nz/~wwifs/mathnews/Nzms84/news84a.shtml |title=New Zealand Mathematical Societu Newsletter Number 84, April 2002 |publisher=Massey.ac.nz |date= |accessdate=2017-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.journals.elsevier.com/topology-and-its-applications/news/mary-ellen-rudin-december-7-1924-march-18-2013/|title=Mary Ellen Rudin (December 7, 1924 ‚Äì March 18, 2013)|publisher=webpage of [[Topology and its Applications]] published by [[Elsevier]]|accessdate=8 April 2013}}</ref>
1971: The [[Association for Women in Mathematics]] (AWM) was founded. It is a professional society whose mission is to encourage women and girls to study and to have active careers in the mathematical sciences, and to promote equal opportunity for and the equal treatment of women and girls in the mathematical sciences. It is incorporated in America in the state of Massachusetts.<ref name="google">{{cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/site/awmmath/awm|title=About AWM - AWM Association for Women in Mathematics|publisher=sites.google.com|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
1971: The [[Joint Committee on Women in the Mathematical Sciences]] (JCW), was founded as a committee of the American Mathematical Society (AMS). It is now a joint committee of seven mathematical and statistical societies which works to identify mechanisms for the enhancement of opportunities for women in the mathematical and statistical sciences, recommend actions to the governing bodies of the member societies in support of these opportunities, and document its recommendations by presenting data.<ref name="wordpress">{{cite web|url=http://jcwmath.wordpress.com/|title=JCW-Math | Joint Committee on Women in the Mathematical Sciences|publisher=jcwmath.wordpress.com|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
1973: American mathematician [[Jean Taylor]] published her dissertation on ‚ÄúRegularity of the Singular Set of Two-Dimensional Area-Minimizing Flat Chains Modulo 3 in R3‚Äù which solved a long-standing problem about length and smoothness of soap-film triple function curves.<ref name="agnesscott6">{{cite web|url=http://www.agnesscott.edu/lriddle/women/jtaylor.htm|title=Jean Taylor|publisher=agnesscott.edu|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
1974: American mathematician [[Joan Birman]] published the book ''Braids, Links, and Mapping Class Groups''. It has become a standard introduction, with many of today‚Äôs researchers having learned the subject through it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ams.org/notices/200701/fea-birman.pdf |title=Interview with Joan Birman |publisher=Ams.org |accessdate=2014-03-04}}</ref>
1975‚Äì1977: American amateur mathematician [[Marjorie Rice]], who had no formal training in mathematics beyond high school, discovered three new types of tessellating pentagons and more than sixty distinct tessellations by pentagons.<ref name="camosun">{{cite web|url=http://britton.disted.camosun.bc.ca/jbperplex.htm|title=Perplexing Pentagons|author=Doris Schattschneider|publisher=britton.disted.camosun.bc.ca|accessdate=2014-01-25|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160813111016/http://britton.disted.camosun.bc.ca/jbperplex.htm|archivedate=2016-08-13|df=}}</ref>
1975: American mathematician [[Julia Robinson]] became the first female mathematician elected to the National Academy of Sciences.<ref name="awm-math.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.awm-math.org/noetherbrochure/Robinson82.html|title=Profiles of Women in Mathematics: Julia Robinson|publisher=awm-math.org|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
1979: [[Mary Ellen Rudin]] became the first woman to present the Earle Raymond Hedrick Lectures; these lectures were established by the Mathematical Association of America in 1952 to present to the Association a lecturer of known skill as an expositor of mathematics "who will present a series of at most three lectures accessible to a large fraction of those who teach college mathematics."<ref name="agnesscott3"/>
1979: American mathematician [[Dorothy Lewis Bernstein]] became the first female president of the [[Mathematical Association of America]].<ref name="google2">{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of World Scientists|author=Oakes, E.H.|year=2007|publisher=Facts On File, Incorporated|isbn=9781438118826|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=uPRB-OED1bcC}}</ref>
1981: Canadian-American mathematician [[Cathleen Morawetz]] became the first female mathematician to give a Josiah Willard Gibbs Lecture; these lectures are of a semi-popular nature and are given by invitation, and are usually devoted to mathematics or its applications.<ref name="agnesscott3"/><ref name="agnesscott7">{{cite web|url=http://www.agnesscott.edu/lriddle/women/morawetz.htm|title=Cathleen Morawetz|publisher=agnesscott.edu|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
1981: American mathematician [[Doris Schattschneider]] became the first female editor of ''[[Mathematics Magazine]].''<ref name="parson">{{citation|url=http://math.unca.edu/parsons-lecture/2005/bio|title=2005 Parson Lecturer - Dr. Doris Schattschneider|publisher=[[University of North Carolina at Asheville]], Department of Mathematics|accessdate=2013-07-13|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140111191254/http://math.unca.edu/parsons-lecture/2005/bio|archivedate=2014-01-11|df=}}</ref><ref name="bwm">{{citation|url=http://www.agnesscott.edu/lriddle/women/schatt.htm|title=Doris Schattschneider|series=Biographies of Women Mathematicians|publisher=[[Agnes Scott College]]|date=April 5, 2013|accessdate=2013-07-13|first=Larry|last=Riddle}}</ref>
1983: [[Julia Robinson]] became the first female president of the American Mathematical Society.<ref name="awm-math.org"/>
1983: [[Julia Robinson]] became the first female mathematician to be awarded a [[MacArthur Fellowship]].<ref name="agnesscott3"/>
1988: [[Doris Schattschneider]] became the first woman to present the J. Sutherland Frame Lectures, which are presented at the summer meeting of the Mathematical Association of America.<ref name="agnesscott3"/>
1992: American mathematician [[Gloria Gilmer]] became the first woman to deliver a major National Association of Mathematicians lecture (it was the Cox‚ÄìTalbot address).<ref name="buffalo2">{{cite web|url=http://www.math.buffalo.edu/mad/PEEPS/gilmer_gloria.html|title=Gloria Ford Gilmer|publisher=math.buffalo.edu|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
1995: American mathematician [[Margaret H. Wright|Margaret Wright]] became the first female president of the [[Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics]].<ref name="agnesscott3"/>
1995: Israeli-Canadian mathematician [[Leah Keshet|Leah Edelstein-Keshet]] became the first female president of the [[Society for Mathematical Biology]].<ref name="math">{{cite web|url=http://www.math.ubc.ca/~keshet/keshet.html|title=Leah Edelstein-Keshet|publisher=math.ubc.ca|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
1996: [[Joan Birman]] became the first woman to receive the [[Chauvenet Prize]], which is awarded annually by the Mathematical Association of America to the author of an outstanding expository article on a mathematical topic by a member of the association.<ref name="agnesscott3"/>
1996: [[Ioana Dumitriu]], a New York University sophomore from Romania, became the first woman to be named a [[Putnam Fellow]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Karen W. Arenson |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/01/nyregion/q-how-many-women-have-won-the-top-math-contest.html |title=Q: How Many Women Have Won the Top Math Contest? - New York Times |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=1997-05-01 |accessdate=2014-03-04}}</ref> Putnam Fellows are the top five (or six, in case of a tie) scorers on The William Lowell Putnam Mathematical Competition.<ref name="duke">{{cite web|url=http://www.dukemagazine.duke.edu/issues/010210/figure-where.html|title=Duke Magazine-Where Are They Now?-January/February 2010|publisher=dukemagazine.duke.edu|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref><ref name="jhu">{{cite web|url=https://cogito.cty.jhu.edu/15504/melanie-wood-the-making-of-a-mathematician/|title=Melanie Wood: The Making of a Mathematician - Cogito|publisher=cogito.cty.jhu.edu|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
1998: [[Melanie Wood]] became the first female American to make the U.S. International Math Olympiad Team. She won silver medals in the 1998 and 1999 International Mathematical Olympiads.<ref name="nytimes">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/10/education/10math.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|title=The New York Times|publisher=nytimes.com|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
2002: [[Susan Howson]] became the first woman to win the [[Adams Prize]], given annually by the University of Cambridge to a British mathematician under the age of 40.<ref name="agnesscott3"/>
2002: [[Melanie Wood]] became the first American woman and second woman overall to be named a Putnam Fellow in 2002.<ref>{{cite web|author=Bridget Booher |url=http://www.dukemagazine.duke.edu/issues/010210/figure-where.html |title=Duke Magazine-Where Are They Now?-January/February 2010 |publisher=Dukemagazine.duke.edu |date=2009-07-13 |accessdate=2014-03-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cogito.org/Articles/ArticleDetail.aspx?ContentID=15504|title=Melanie Wood: The Making of a Mathematician|last=Scharf|first=Deepti|date=May 8, 2003|website=Duke News & Communications|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100707151220/http://www.cogito.org/Articles/ArticleDetail.aspx?ContentID=15504|archivedate=July 7, 2010|deadurl=yes|accessdate=February 10, 2014}}</ref><ref name="ams">{{cite web|url=http://www.ams.org/notices/200404/comm-morgan.pdf |title=2003 Morgan Prize |publisher=Ams.org |accessdate=2014-03-04}}</ref>
2004: [[Melanie Wood]] became the first woman to win the Frank and Brennie Morgan Prize for Outstanding Research in Mathematics by an Undergraduate Student. It is an annual award given to an undergraduate student in the US, Canada, or Mexico who demonstrates superior mathematics research.<ref name="ams"/>
2004: American [[Alison Miller]] became the first ever female gold medal winner on the U.S. International Math Olympiad Team.<ref name="mathforum">{{cite web|url=http://mathforum.org/announce/congrats_alison.html|title=Math Forum @ Drexel: Congratulations, Alison!|publisher=mathforum.org|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
2006: Polish-Canadian mathematician [[Nicole Tomczak-Jaegermann]] became the first woman to win the [[CRM-Fields-PIMS prize]], which recognizes exceptional achievement in the mathematical sciences.<ref name="agnesscott3"/><ref name="utoronto">{{cite web|url=http://www.fields.utoronto.ca/press/05-06/tomczak-jaegermann.html|title=Fields Institute - CRM-Fields Prize Recipients|publisher=fields.utoronto.ca|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
2006: [[Stefanie Petermichl]], a German [[mathematical analysis|mathematical analyst]] then at the University of Texas at Austin, became the first woman to win the [[Salem Prize]], an annual award given to young mathematicians considered to have done outstanding work in [[Raphael Salem]]'s field of interest, primarily Fourier series and related areas in analysis.<ref name="cv">[https://www.math.univ-toulouse.fr/~petermic/short_vita.html Short vita], retrieved 2016-07-04.</ref><ref name="agnesscott3"/> She shared the prize with [[Artur Avila]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.media.uzh.ch/en/Press-Releases/2018/Artur-Avila.html |title=UZH - Fields Medal Winner Artur Avila Appointed Full Professor at the University of Zurich |publisher=Media.uzh.ch |date=2018-07-24 |accessdate=2018-10-09}}</ref><ref name="cv">[https://www.math.univ-toulouse.fr/~petermic/short_vita.html Short vita], retrieved 2016-07-04.</ref>
2012: Latvian mathematician [[Daina Taimina]] became the first woman to win the [[Euler Book Prize]], which is awarded annually to an author or authors of an outstanding book about mathematics, for her book ''Crocheting Adventures with Hyperbolic Planes.''<ref name="agnesscott3"/><ref name="bbc">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/8589455.stm|title=BBC News - Odd title prize for crochet book|publisher=news.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
2012: The [[Working Committee for Women in Mathematics]], Chinese Mathematical Society (WCWM-CMS) was founded; it is a national non-profit academic organization in which female mathematicians who are engaged in research, teaching, and applications of mathematics can share their scientific research through academic exchanges both in China and abroad.<ref name="agnesscott8">{{cite web|url=http://www.agnesscott.edu/lriddle/women/women.htm|title=Women Mathematicians, Sponsored by Agnes Scott College|publisher=agnesscott.edu|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref> It is one of the branches of the [[Chinese Mathematical Society]] (CMS).<ref name="agnesscott8"/>
2014: [[Maryam Mirzakhani]] became the first woman as well as the first Iranian to be awarded the [[Fields Medal]], which she was awarded for "her outstanding contributions to the dynamics and geometry of [[Riemann surfaces]] and their moduli spaces."<ref name="themarysue">{{cite web|url=http://www.themarysue.com/woman-wins-fields-medal-for-first-time/|title=Maryam Mirzakhani Becomes First Woman to Earn Fields Medal for Mathematics in Its 78 Year History | The Mary Sue|publisher=themarysue.com|accessdate=2014-09-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.mathunion.org/general/prizes/2014/prize-citations/ | publisher = International Mathematical Union | title = IMU Prizes 2014 citations| accessdate = 2014-08-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.mathunion.org/general/prizes/2014/| publisher = International Mathematical Union | title = IMU Prizes 2014| accessdate = 2014-08-12}}</ref> She shared the prize with [[Martin Hairer]], [[Manjul Bhargava]], and [[Artur Avila]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mathunion.org/imu-awards/fields-medal/fields-medals-2014 |title=Fields Medals 2014 | International Mathematical Union (IMU) |publisher=Mathunion.org |date=2014-08-13 |accessdate=2018-10-09}}</ref> It is a prize awarded to two, three, or four mathematicians not over 40 years of age at each [[International Congress of Mathematicians|International Congress]] of the [[International Mathematical Union]], and is often viewed as the greatest honor a mathematician can receive.<ref>{{cite journal| title = 2006 Fields Medals awarded | journal = [[Notices of the American Mathematical Society]]| volume = 53|issue = 9|publisher= [[American Mathematical Society]]|date=October 2006 | url = http://www.ams.org/notices/200609/comm-prize-fields.pdf| pages= 1037‚Äì1044|format=PDF}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/technology/story/2006/08/22/math-fields.html|title=Reclusive Russian turns down math world's highest honour|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=22 August 2006|accessdate=2006-08-26}}</ref>
2016: French mathematician [[Claire Voisin]] received the [[CNRS Gold medal]], the highest scientific research award in France.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www2.cnrs.fr/en/2815.htm | title=Mathematician Claire Voisin awarded the CNRS 2016 gold medal}}</ref>
==See also== [[Timeline of women in mathematics in the United States]]

'''Virginalist''' denotes a composer of the so-called virginalist school, and usually refers to the English [[Keyboard instrument|keyboard]] composers of the late [[Tudor dynasty|Tudor]] and early [[Jacobean era|Jacobean]] periods. The term does not appear to have been applied earlier than the 19th century. Although the [[virginals]] was among the most popular keyboard instruments of this period, there is no evidence that the composers wrote exclusively for this instrument, and their music is equally suited to the [[harpsichord]], the [[clavichord]] or the [[Organ (music)#Chamber organs|chamber organ]].
The term is sometimes also applied to other northern European composers of this period, such as [[Jan Pieterszoon Sweelinck]] and [[Samuel Scheidt]].

'''Vladimir Nevezhin''' ({{lang-ru|–í–ª–∞–¥–∏–º–∏—Ä –ê–ª–µ–∫—Å–∞–Ω–¥—Ä–æ–≤–∏—á –ù–µ–≤–µ–∂–∏–Ω}}) is a [[Russians|Russian]] historian (''Doctor of History Sciences''), is working as a professor in [[Moscow]], chief scientific collaborator at the ''Institute of Russian History'' (of the [[Russian Academy of Science]]) and member of the editorial board of the journal ''–û—Ç–µ—á–µ—Å—Ç–≤–µ–Ω–Ω–∞—è –∏—Å—Ç–æ—Ä–∏—è'' (''History of the Fatherland'').
During the 1990s, he took part in the discussion and dispute over the pre-history of the [[Great Patriotic War]]. Nevezhin has analysed the content of Stalin's speeches, propagandistic directives in spring 1941 and notes of the contemporaries, drawing conclusions that the numerous documents unambiguously expressed the preparations of the country for an offensive in 1941.

{{Infobox collection | name = Women of Rock Oral History Project | image = | image_caption = | alt = | housed_at = [[Smith College]] | curators = | funded_by = | website = {{URL|womenofrock.org|WomenOfRock.org}} }} '''Women of Rock Oral History Project''' is an oral history project based at [[Smith College]] focusing on American women and [[gender non-conformance|gender non-conforming]], [[LGBT]], and [[feminism|feminist]] [[rock and roll]] and [[punk music]] musicians from the 1970s to the present.<ref name=FeministMag-WomenOfRock-2017>{{cite news|last1=Jasmine|first1=Lucretia Tye|last2=Pearson|first2=Tanya|title=FM Jan 10: SafetyPin Box / GameChangers / Women of Rock|url=http://feministmagazine.org/2017/01/fm-jan-10/|work=Feminist Magazine|date=9 January 2017|format=Radio show}}</ref><ref name=FeministMag-WomenOfRock-Audio-2017>{{cite news|last1=Jasmine|first1=Lucretia Tye|last2=Pearson|first2=Tanya|title=FM Jan 10: SafetyPin Box / GameChangers / Women of Rock|url=http://archive.kpfk.org/mp3/kpfk_170110_150050femmag.MP3|work=Feminist Magazine|date=9 January 2017|format=Audio|quote=Starts at 33:45}}</ref><ref name=Smith-RedressingRockHistory-2015>{{cite news|last1=Hobbes|first1=M|title=Redressing Rock History: Tanya Pearson ‚ÄòAC Creates ‚ÄòWomen of Rock‚Äô Collection at Smith|url=https://www.smith.edu/news/redressing-rock-history/|work=Gr√©court Gate, [[Smith College]]|date=14 October 2015}}</ref>
== History == The Women of Rock Oral History project was started in December 2014 as a collection of digital video interviews conducted by [[Smith College]] [[Ada Comstock]] scholar and archivist, Tanya Pearson.<ref name=WomenOfRockOralHistoryProject-FindingAid-2014>{{cite news|title=Women of Rock Oral History Project oral histories, 2014-2017 (MS 756)|url=http://asteria.fivecolleges.edu/findaids/sophiasmith/mnsss590.html|work=[[Smith College]]|date=2014|format=Finding aid}}</ref>
The inspiration for the project came from a seminar on [[censorship]] in the United States Pearson took while at [[Smith College|Smith]], where she worked as an assistant archivist at the Sophia Smith Collection while completing an undergraduate degree in American Studies with concentrations in oral history and archives. For the seminar, Pearson wrote about women rockers from the 1990s. During the process she was discouraged at the difficulty of finding widely available information about musicians she needed to find source material on, illustrating the fact that bands like [[L7 (band)|L7]] were not covered in detail in rock and roll history.<ref name=Smith-RedressingRockHistory-2015 /> Thematic devices she saw seemed to devalue their music and their musicianship, where the musicians were subject to [[sexism]] and [[tokenism]], especially in popular journalism.<ref name=HalfHoursOfPowerShow-Podcast>{{cite web|last1=Pio|last2=Chelsie|last3=Pearson|first3=Tanya|title=THHOP: Women of Rock Oral History Project [2/11/2016]|url=https://soundcloud.com/oliomedia/womenofrock|website=The Half Hours Of Power Show|publisher=Olio Media|language=en|format=Podcast|date=11 February 2016}}</ref> The project highlights the limitations and bias within music scholarship and journalism.<ref name=Vanyaland-Feature-2016>{{cite news|last1=Marotta|first1=Michael|title=Women of Rock Oral History Project aims to create equal representation in music's narrative|url=http://www.vanyaland.com/2016/03/01/women-of-rock-oral-history-project-aims-to-create-equal-representation-in-musics-narrative/|work=Vanyaland|date=1 March 2016}}</ref> Many of the musicians were also active pre-internet, where press and coverage weren't available online and are not digitized.<ref name=DailyHampshire-RightingTheWrongs-2015>{{cite news|last1=Willingham|first1=Leah|title=Women who rock: Sophia Smith Collection introduces first-ever oral-history project about female rock ‚Äòn‚Äô rollers|url=http://www.gazettenet.com/Archives/2015/09/womenrockers-hg-102215|work=[[Daily Hampshire Gazette]]|date=10 December 2015}}</ref>
The project includes written transcripts and is housed at the Sophia Smith Collection at [[Smith College]].<ref name=DailyHampshire-RightingTheWrongs-2015 /><ref name=Preview-WomenOfRock-2017>{{cite news|last1=Drane|first1=Amanda|title=Rocking the Project: Tanya Pearson wants to acquaint you with the women who helped forge rock and roll|url=https://view.publitas.com/p222-4389/preview-april-2017/page/20-21|work=Preview Massachusetts|date=April 2017|pages=20-22|language=en}}</ref> The scope of the project is to document the influence and history of women in rock and roll, and to bring focus to the unheralded role of women musicians.<ref name=ValleyAdvocate-Feature-2016>{{cite news|last1=Drane|first1=Amanda|title=Women Rock: sexism and music go together like rock and roll|url=http://valleyadvocate.com/2016/01/25/women-rock/|work=[[Valley Advocate]]|date=25 January 2016}}</ref>
=== Methods === The digital interviews with the musicians is the core focus of the project.<ref name=HalfHoursOfPowerShow-Podcast /> [[Nina Gordon]] and [[Louise Post]], who make up [[Veruca Salt]], were the first band and musicians that were interviewed. The interviews include biographies of their lives and their work as musicians. A portion of each interview includes what it was like to work as a musician in the time period that they were active as well as their experiences in the current day.<ref name=DailyHampshire-RightingTheWrongs-2015 />
As a supplemental part of the project, the Women of Rock Oral History Project has conducted panels and roundtable discussions often with some of the subjects of the interviews to discuss issues of gender gap and challenges women face in the music industry.<ref name=HalfHoursOfPowerShow-Podcast /><ref name=RightingTheWrongsPanel-2015>{{cite news|title=Righting the Wrongs of Rock History Panel|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ulHaCUuEDlQ|work=Women of Rock Oral History Project|date=22 October 2015|language=en|format=Video panel recording}}</ref><ref name=NEPR-RightingTheWrongsPanel-2015>{{cite news|title=Righting the Wrongs of Rock History Panel|url=https://soundcloud.com/newenglandpublicradio/rightingthewrongsofrockhistorypanel|work=[[New England Public Radio]]|date=22 October 2015|language=en|format=Audio panel recording}}</ref><ref name=Sophian-RightingTheWrongsPanel-2015>{{cite news|last1=Going|first1=Eliza|title=Recognizing Women in Rock Music|url=http://www.thesmithsophian.com/recognizing-women-in-rock-music/|work=The Sophian|publisher=[[Smith College]]|date=29 October 2015}}</ref><ref name=ClickWorkspace-PanelDiscussion-2016>{{cite news|title=P L A T F O R M 5: Tanya Pearson // Sam Chaplin // Sara Smith|url=http://clickworkspace.org/events/2016/9/30/p-l-a-t-f-o-r-m-5-tanya-pearson-sam-chaplin-sara-smith|work=Click Workspace|date=4 November 2016}}</ref>
Pearson has also organized concerts, local shows, and events in support of the grassroots project, which often includes performances by subjects of the oral histories.<ref name=SoundingOut-LePoissonRouge-2017>{{cite news|last1=Bad Cover Version|title=An Evening with Three Legendary Rebel Women at Le Poisson Rouge, January 27, 2017: Margot Olavarria, Bibbe Hansen, and Alice Bag|url=https://soundstudiesblog.com/2017/03/23/an-evening-with-three-legendary-rebel-women-at-le-poisson-rouge-january-27-2017-alice-bag-bibbe-hansen-and-margot-olavarria/|work=Sounding Out!|date=23 March 2017}}</ref> As part of these performances, another component of the project is addressing [[gender bias on Wikipedia]] and its coverage of women and [[gender non-conformance|gender non-conforming]] musicians by holding strategy discussions and Wikipedia editathons.<ref name=ValleyAdvocate-WikiRant-2017>{{cite news|last1=Meyer|first1=Will|title=Basemental: A Wikipedia Rant by Will|url=http://valleyadvocate.com/2017/11/20/basemental-a-wikipedia-rant-by-will/|work=[[Valley Advocate]]|date=20 November 2017}}</ref>
=== Funding === The project has been funded by a Rosenthal Fund grant from [[Smith College]] and a [[Helen Gurley Brown]] Magic Grant awarded to Ada Comstock Scholars.<ref name=Smith-RosenthalFund>{{cite web|title=Smith College: Archives Concentration ‚Äì The Rosenthal Fund|url=https://www.smith.edu/archives/rosenthal.php|website=[[Smith College]]}}</ref><ref name=Smith-MagicGrant-2016>{{cite news|last1=Hobbes|first1=M|title=Two Smithies Awarded Magic Grants for Novel Oral History Projects|url=https://www.smith.edu/news/two-smithies-awarded-magic-grants-for-novel-oral-history-projects/|work=Gr√©court Gate, [[Smith College]]|date=24 June 2016}}</ref>
== Collection == The project includes over 20 underrepresented female musicians from various [[rock and roll]] and [[punk music]] bands that were active from the 1970s to 2010, with some musicians and bands still actively performing music. Bands are listed next to each subject below. Each musician participated in video interviews which were digitized and made available on [[Vimeo]]. There are over 29 videos that are part of the project.<ref name=ValleyAdvocate-MissingWiki-2017>{{cite news|last1=Levesque|first1=Jennifer|title=Valley Show Girl: The Case of the Missing Wiki Edits|url=http://valleyadvocate.com/2017/11/13/the-case-of-the-missing-wiki-edits/|work=[[Valley Advocate]]|date=13 November 2017}}</ref> A corresponding transcription project corresponding to the videos is in process of being created.<ref name=WomenOfRockOralHistoryProject-FindingAid-2014 />
The timeframe of the project is from December 2014 to the present.<ref name=ValleyAdvocate-MissingWiki-2017 /> The collection is ongoing, with additional video interviews being conducted.<ref name=WomenOfRockOralHistoryProject-FindingAid-2014 /> Pearson has said that the priority of subjects is on women musicians from the 1960s and 1970s, in an effort to capture their stories before their stories are lost.<ref name=ValleyAdvocate-Feature-2016 /> A book that focuses on the stories of pioneering women musicians in rock is planned.<ref name=Smith-MagicGrant-2016 />

{{Infobox organization | name = World Archaeological Congress | native_name = | native_name_lang = | named_after = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map2 = | map2_size = | map2_alt = | map2_caption = | abbreviation = WAC | motto = | predecessor = 1986 | merged = | successor = | formation = <!-- use {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | founder = | founding_location = | extinction = <!-- use {{end date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | merger = | type = | tax_id = <!-- or | vat_id = (for European organizations) --> | registration_id = <!-- for non-profit org --> | status = | purpose = | headquarters = | location = | coords = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|display=inline,title}} --> | region = | services = | products = | methods = | fields = | membership = | membership_year = | language = | owner = <!-- or | owners = --> | sec_gen = | leader_title = Presidents | leader_name = Koji Mizoguchi | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | board_of_directors = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | secessions = | affiliations = | budget = | budget_year = | revenue = | revenue_year = | disbursements = | expenses = | expenses_year = | endowment = | staff = | staff_year = | volunteers = | volunteers_year = | slogan = | mission = | website = {{URL|http://worldarch.org/}} | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = }} The '''World Archaeological Congress''' (WAC) is a non-governmental, not-for-profit organization which promotes world archaeology. It is the only global archaeological organisation with elected representation.
Established in 1986, WAC holds an international Congress every four years to promote the exchange of results from archaeological research; professional training and public education for disadvantaged nations, groups and communities; the empowerment and betterment of Indigenous groups and [[First Nations peoples]]; and the conservation of archaeological sites.
==History==
The World Archaeological Congress was established in 1986, after the controversial 11th meeting of the [[International Union for Prehistoric and Protohistoric Sciences]] was banned from meeting in [[Southampton|Southampton, Great Britain]] during which the Southampton City Council and other organizations funding the meeting demanded that scholars from [[South Africa]] and [[Namibia]] were banned from participation in view of [[Apartheid in South Africa]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Golson|first=Jack|title=The World Archaeological Congress, Southampton, and its aftermath|journal=Australian Archaeology|year=1986|volume=23|url=http://blindio.library.uq.edu.au/ojs/index.php/aa/article/view/1582/0|accessdate=11 May 2012}}</ref> The British organizers complied with this demand, but the Executive Committee of UISPP ultimately ruled that it was against the organization's constitution to exclude any international scholars, and withdrew the conference. The National Secretary of the Congress, [[Peter Ucko]], moved forward with the meeting under a new name, the World Archaeological Congress.<ref>{{cite web|last=Gero|first=Joan|title=Why? And Whither? WAC|url=http://www.nps.gov/seac/gero.htm|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=11 May 2012}}</ref> The resulting meeting drew in 1000 people from 100 countries, with the special attempt to include people from new nations and minority groups to participate in the congress.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Golson|first=Jack|title=The World Archaeological Congress, Southampton, and its aftermath|journal=Australian Archaeology|year=1986|volume=23|url=http://blindio.library.uq.edu.au/ojs/index.php/aa/article/view/1582/0|accessdate=11 May 2012}}</ref> Since that time, WAC has "constituted itself as a uniquely representative non-profit organization of worldwide archaeology that recognizes the historical and social role, and the political context, of archaeology, and the need to make archaeological studies relevant to the wider community. It especially seeks to debate and refute institutionalized views that serve the interests of a privileged few to the detriment of disenfranchised others. WAC explicitly values diversity against institutionalized mechanisms that marginalize the cultural heritage of [[indigenous peoples]], [[minorities]] and the [[poverty|poor]]".<ref>{{cite web|last=Gero|first=Joan|title=Why? And Whither? WAC|url=http://www.nps.gov/seac/gero.htm|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=11 May 2012}}</ref>
==Congresses==
World Archaeological Congresses are held every four years, with several Inter-Congresses between the main congresses. The congresses vary in their seasonality, but present the opportunity to present research, participate in panels, and socialize with other members. Congresses have been held on six continents and attract large, multinational attendance. The locations of the congresses are chosen to encourage inclusivity within the means of people from around the world.<ref>Stone, Peter. 2006. ‚ÄòAll Smoke and Mirrors...‚Äô The World Archaeological Congress 1986-2004, in A Future for Archaeology, eds. Layton, R. Shennan, S. and Stone, P. UCL Press, London. 41-45.</ref> Locating congresses outside of 'First World' venues has led to political and social complications for WAC. For example, WAC-3 in India was besieged by media coverage after the then president of the international executive committee J. Golson banned discussion of the destruction of the [[Ayodhya dispute|Ayodhya mosque]] during the conference.<ref>Bernbeck, Reinhard and Pollock, Susan. 1996. Ayodhya, Archaeology, and Identity. Current Anthropology, Vol. 37, No. 1, Supplement: Special Issue: Anthropology in Public. S138-S142.</ref>
Patrons for past Congresses have included [[Prince Charles]] (WAC-1), [[Nelson Mandela]] (WAC-4), [[Harriet Fulbright]] (WAC-5), and [[Abdullah II of Jordan]] (WAC-7)

==Inter-Congresses==
The World Archaeological Congress holds Inter-Congresses which are regionally and thematically organized. Locations include [[Vermillion, South Dakota]], [[Mombasa|Mombasa, Kenya]], [[Braƒç|Braƒç, Croatia]], [[Catamarca Province|Caramarca, Argentina]], [[Kingston, Jamaica]], [[Osaka|Osaka, Japan]], [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle, Great Britain]], [[L√≥dz|L√≥dz, Poland]], [[Olavarr√≠a|Olavarr√≠a, Argentina]], [[New Zealand]], [[Cura√ßao]], [[Ramallah|Ramallah, Palestine]] and [[Indianapolis|Indianapolis, Indiana]].
==Publications==
Selected papers from these conferences are published in the [http://www.worldarchaeologicalcongress.org/publications/books/48-one-world-archaeology One World Archaeology] Series. In mid-2012 there were 58 books in this series. WAC also publishes [http://www.worldarchaeologicalcongress.org/publications/journals/279-archaeologies-the-journal-of-the-world-archaeological-congress Archaeologies, the Journal of the World Archaeological Congress]. A [http://www.worldarchaeologicalcongress.org/publications full list] of the book series and journals that WAC publishes is available.
==Protocols==
The World Archaeological Congress has produced ground-breaking [http://www.worldarchaeologicalcongress.org/about-wac/codes-of-ethics/167-codes-of-ethics Codes of Ethics] for the conduct of archaeologists. These include the Vermillion Accord on Human Remains which calls for respect for the dead and descendent communities and the Tamaki Makau-rau Accord on the Display of Human Remains and Sacred Objects which requires permission from community members before displaying human remains and artifacts.
==Global Libraries Program== The [http://www.worldarchaeologicalcongress.org/activities/global-libraries/198-global-libraries-program Global Libraries Program] aims to develop the archaeological literary collections of economically-disadvantaged institutions. By supporting such libraries, we hope to assist archaeological and cultural heritage management students and professionals to undertake and excel at their study and work.
==WAC Presidents== Michael Day (1986‚Äì1990), [[Jack Golson]] (1990‚Äì1994), Bassey Wai Andah (1994‚Äì1997), Gilbert Pwiti (Acting 1998-1999), [[Martin Hall (academic)|Martin Hall]] (1999‚Äì2003), [[Claire Smith]] (2003‚Äì2013), Koji Mizoguchi (2013‚Äìpresent)
